metadata.title: On the initiation of DD reactions in the zirconium-deuterium system

affiliation: lntitute of Physical Chrmistry. Russian Acndiemry of Sciences. AMoso, Ruma

abstract.text: The posibility of initialing DD reartions on vibro-milling of zirconium together with beavy water and deuterated polypropylene has been investigased. Wcak emistion of neutrons has been desected both during the vibre-miling proces and some timme afierits completaon.

body_text.text: At present, an active investigation of the possi-bilties of carrying out nuciear synthesis reactions (of the DD type) is going on in metal-deuterium sy's-tems $[ 1-3 ]$ . The results obtained prove to be extremely conflicting and require thorough analysis. It is clear, however, that the possibility of observing DD reactions and the corresponding ncutrons depends both on the conditions of sample preparation and on the experimental conditions. In this connection. metals of group IV of the periodic system are of the greatest interest, since these are able to be strongly saturated by deuterium (the ratio of dcuterium to metal is 2: $D$ and possess very low equilibnum phase pressures of deuterium, say, $1 0^{-4}-1 0^{-3}$ mm Hg [4].

Now, to increase the dissolution rate of deuterium in the lattice of such metals requires a high dispersity of the powder particles used. Moreover, to attain a high deuternium dissolution rate the surface of the metal samples should be saturated by dislocutions and point defects that serve as sinks of deuterium and as catalysts of the dccomposition of $\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\mathbf{D}_{2}$ molecules into atoms (4]. In our opinion, the latter cir-cumistance is one of the causes of the poor repro-ducibihity of the results of the inituation of DD reactions in the titansum-dcuternum system whether in the course of saturation of titanium from the gas phase or during electrolysis in D,O [1.5). The thermal vacuum treatment of titanium in the deuterium atmosphere also does not lead to an increase in the reactivity of the samples, since this does not cause the formation of a fresh surface.

The sugested method of carrying out DD reactions of synthesis is free from such a substanial drawback. The method is based on the inpcction of deuterium through the freshly formed titanium surface which possesses a high reactivity and has not had sufficient time to undergo oxidation during the characteristic time of failure of the sumples, amounting to less than 10-* s (the characteristic time of the developing of a crack through a particle having a transverse dimension smaller than I mm).

We have already shown eartier the essential possibility of gcneration of neutrons in the titanium-deuterium system in the course of the dispersion of titanium in a vibro-mill together with deuterated substances [3,6].

As has been demonstrated in refs. [3.6]. just such a atio of dcuterated components in the course of vi-bro-miling (deuterating) of titanium brings about the maximum effect of generation of neutrons. For companson, individual milling of Zr was camed out, as well as vibro-milling of a Zr+4% PP(H.) + 10% H.O mixture - that is, under the conditions that deuterium is absent from the system (blank experiments ). Afler a total milling time of 1800 s, the spe-cifie surface of the obtained ZrD, powder was measured by the BET method in accordance with the low-temperature adsorption of nitrogen, and amounted to abou1 6.0 m-/g for the Zr+ 4% PP(D,)+ 10% D.0 systems. After vibro-milling. part of the ZrD, powder was dried and then rinsed in boiling benzene for the purpose of removing polypropylene. Subsequently the deuterium content was cvaluated by the high-temperature extraction mcthod. As was experimentally shown, in 30 min of vibro-milling the value of $.$ amounted to about 1.8. However, it will have to be noted that this value cannot be regarded as being very accurate, since no total washing off of polymer occurs, whose pyrolysis products may to a sufficient degree distort the results of measuring the content of deuterium in zirconnum.
All the experiments of the present Letter were carried out in an ecentric ball vibro-mill having an applied power of 10 W/g, as described in refs. [3.6].

The recording of the neutrons was effected by the usc of a unit made of seven proporional countcrs immersed into a cadmium covered tank filled with vacuum oil. The dimensions of the tank were 250x250x700 mm'. The recording circuit is de-scnbed in refs. [ 3.6]. The detector cfficicncy was determined by the use of a calibrated Po-a- Be neutron source having an iniensity of 200 neutrons/s, which was placed into a cell of the vibro-mill instead of the working drum. Dunng the whole working pericxd. the natural neutron background was also taken into account as measured with the working drum not in the cell. The cosmic background was fairly permanent, and amounted to about 0.030 ncutrons/'s.

During the experiments, the shape and duration of the pules being recorded were continuously controlled by the use of a memory oscillograph, and compared with similar parameters of the pulses of neutrons yielded by the Po-a-Be souree. Thus ncu-tron source has a maximum neutron energy of about 3 MeV. which is close lo the maximum energy of neutrons resulting from the d +d-- He+ n reactions. Measuremenis carried out with the use of a neutron source have demonstrated that mosi of the pulses have an energy corresponding to that of channels 2-32 of the Al-264 style amplitude analyzer used by us (fig. la). Therefore, we identify the pulses gelting into channels 1-1l of the analyzer with electromag-netie disturbances. As has been shown by the experiments, both in the vibre-milling process (fhig. Ib. Ic) and after swinching t off, the number of pulses in the low-amplitude channels is insignaficant as compared with that of the "neutron" pulses that are recorded in channels 12-32 of the analyrer. Therefore, we concluded that there was a minimum influence of the electromagnetic and acoustic microphone on the reliability of the experimental results.
Control experiments carried out om pure zirconium without deuterium have shown that no exces over the matural neutron background is observed both
in the course of milling Zr (as frozen in liquid nitrogen) and on its completion.
The cxperiments on the deuteration of zirconium were carried out under conditions similar to those described above for the Zr-H system. The algorithm of the experiments was as follows.

Process 2. On switching off the vibro-effect, the dnum remained in the cl, and the neutron background was registered during a period of 10 to 15 mun (the so-called "posl-effect"). In this tume, the temperature of the "outer wall" of the working drum would rise from $0=c$ (on the completion of the vibro-effect) to 25-30"C.

In fig. Ib we present a histogram of the distribution of pulses over the channels of the energy analyzer, which has been obtained during a tosal vibro-milling time of 30 min (e.g. process $1 )$ As appears from fig. 1, the shape of the histogram and the position of the maximum agree well with the norm of the source (fig. 1a). Similar amplitude spectra were obtained for processes $2 ~$ and 3.
is the lewel of trustworthiness of the effect observed (o is the standard deviation ).

As appears from table 1, a substantial increment over the natural background level is observed. The most essential etfect, excceding 7a, is observed in the drum freezing process wnth the object under investigation being in liquid nitrogen. A similar maximum of the effect was also observed for the titanium-deuterium system in the course of freezimg ( 3.6]. The post-effect has also a considerable value, and exceeds ba.
We note that in separate experiments the duration of the alter-emission of ncutrons attaincd 30 to 60 min. However. the cause of the longer duration of the elfect is so far unclear.
The emission of neutroms observed is of a strongly unsteady character.

Hence, if we admit the existence of the pulse ncu-tron processes associated, for example, with the formation of cracks in zirconium [71, whose duration is very short (a few us), then the efficiency of our detector can be reduced by many orders of magnitude, while the real effect may be much higher [5]. Therefore, in the present case. it is desirable to employ detectors having a short "dead"" time.

We have concluded that when the zirconium-deuterium system undergoes mechanical stress. emission of neutrons is observed, which are produced by single or separale DD reactions occurring in the course of the dcuteration of its surface.

We also suppose that generation of neutrons is also possible when other transition metuls that are likely to form deutendes in the presence of deuterated substances, ane subjected to a mechanical treatmeni.
